intro: Tapinanthus oedostemon, commonly known as the parasitic dodder, is a flowering plant in the family Orobanchaceae. It is a hemiparasitic species, meaning it derives some of its nutrients from a host plant while also performing photosynthesis. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers and has a fibrous root system that attaches to its host. It is native to Africa and is often found growing on grasses and other herbaceous plants. Due to its parasitic nature, it can significantly weaken its host and is considered a weed in agricultural settings.
